cluster.display: __________ is drawing conclusions about a population.
Inference is drawing __________ about a population.
Inference is drawing conclusions about a __________.
Probability is the __________ that an event will occur.
__________ is the likelihood that an event will occur.
The probability of an event tells us how __________ it is that the event will occur.
The probability that an event will occur is between __________ and 1.
Probability is always between 0% and __________%.
When P(A) = 0, the event will __________ occur.
When P(A) = __________, the event will never occur.
When P(A) = __________, the event will occur for certain.
The closer P(A) is to 1, the __________ likely it is to occur.
__________ methods of determining probability use a series of trials to produce outcomes that could not be predicted in advance.
Empirical methods of determining probability use a series of trials to produce outcomes that could not be __________ in advance.
We call the possible outcomes of a random experiment the __________.
We call the __________ of a random experiment the sample space..
The probability that an event will not occur is referred to as the __________ of that event.
The probability that an event will __________ is referred to as the complement of that event.
The complement of an event A is notated as P(__________).
The __________ of an event A is notated as P(not A).
P(not A) refers to the chance for all outcomes in the sample space S that are __________.
P(not A) = 1 - __________, or the probability that an event does not occur is equal to 1 minus the probability the event does occur.
When events cannot possibly occur together, they are called ___________.
If two events are __________, they cannot be independent, since if A occurs we know that B will not occur, so B depends on A.
If two events are disjoint, they cannot be __________, since if A occurs we know that B will not occur, so B depends on A.
If two events are disjoint, they cannot be independent, since if A occurs we know that B will not occur, so B __________ on A.
If two events are disjoint, P(A or B) = __________ + P(B).
If two events are disjoint, P(A or B) = P(A)+ __________ .
If A and B are ______, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B).
In probability terms, P(A or B) means P(A), P(B), or _____.
In probability terms, P(A ___ B) means P(A), P(B), or both.
P(A _____ B) refers to the probability that event A and event B both occur together.
For disjoint events, P(_____) will always be 0 because they cannot possibly occur together.
Events are considered to be __________ if one event occurring has no effect on the probability of a second event occurring.
Events are considered to be independent if one event occurring has __________ on the probability of a second event occurring.
If events A and B are __________, P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B).
To solve for P(A or B), we subtract __________ from P(A) + P(B).
